column2: As he ate his breakfast, Monseigneur Welcome remarked gayly to his sister, who said nothing, and to Madame Magloire, who was grumbling under her breath, that one really does not need either fork or spoon, even of wood, in order to dip a bit of bread in a cup of milk.

column2: A pretty idea, truly, said Madame Magloire to herself, as she went and came, "to take in a man like that! and to lodge him close to one's self! And how fortunate that he did nothing but steal!

column2: CHAPTER XIII--LITTLE GERVAIS
column3: CHAPTER thirteen-LITTLE GERVAIS

column2: Jean Valjean left the town as though he were fleeing from it.
column3: Jean Valjean left the town as though he were fleeing from it.

column2: He set out at a very hasty pace through the fields, taking whatever roads and paths presented themselves to him, without perceiving that he was incessantly retracing his steps.
column3: He set out at a very hasty pace through the fields, taking whatever roads and paths presented themselves to him, without perceiving that he was incessantly retracing his steps.

column2: He wandered thus the whole morning, without having eaten anything and without feeling hungry.
column3: He wandered thus the whole morning, without having eaten anything and without feeling hungry.

column2: He was the prey of a throng of novel sensations.
column3: He was the prey of a throng of novel sensations.

column2: He was conscious of a sort of rage; he did not know against whom it was directed.
column3: He was conscious of a sort of rage; he did not know against whom it was directed.

column2: He could not have told whether he was touched or humiliated.
column3: He could not have told whether he was touched or humiliated.

column2: There came over him at moments a strange emotion which he resisted and to which he opposed the hardness acquired during the last twenty years of his life.
column3: There came over him at moments a strange emotion which he resisted and to which he opposed the hardness acquired during the last twenty years of his life.

column2: This state of mind fatigued him. He perceived with dismay that the sort of frightful calm which the injustice of his misfortune had conferred upon him was giving way within him.
column3: This state of mind fatigued him. He perceived with dismay that the sort of frightful calm which the injustice of his misfortune had conferred upon him was giving way within him.

column2: He asked himself what would replace this.
column3: He asked himself what would replace this.

column2: At times he would have actually preferred to be in prison with the gendarmes, and that things should not have happened in this way; it would have agitated him less. Although the season was tolerably far advanced, there were still a few late flowers in the hedge-rows here and there, whose odor as he passed through them in his march recalled to him memories of his childhood. These memories were almost intolerable to him, it was so long since they had recurred to him.
